metadata.case_name: Appellants (Tea Estates/Manufacturers) v. State of Kerala

facts.text: Sales-tax Officer, Special Circle Ernakulam assessed the appellants under the Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Act XI of 1125 M.E., to pay sales-tax on transactions of sale of tea chests at the auctions held at Fort Cochin in the years 1956-57 to 1958-59.
Appellants contended that the sales were exempted from tax by virtue of Art. 286(1)(b) of the Constitution.

Appellants petitioned the High Court of Kerala for writs of certiorari quashing the assessment orders and writs of prohibition restraining collection of tax; Vaidialingam J. rejected the petitions, confirmed by Division Bench.
Tea is a controlled commodity; Parliament enacted Tea Act 19 of 1953 for control of tea industry, including export control, establishing Tea Board.

Under Tea Act: s.3(f) defines export; s.3(g) export allotment; s.17 embargo on export without licence; s.18 no consignment shipped without licence/permit; s.19 Central Govt declares export allotments; s.20 tea estate right to export quota; s.21 right to licences for unexhausted quota, transferable.

Trade in tea in Kerala: Manufacturer obtains export quota rights from Tea Board, sends manufactured tea chests to M/s. T. Stanes & Co. Ltd. for warehousing at Willingdon Island; sold by public auction through brokers at Fort Cochin with export quota rights.

At auction, bids for tea chests with export quota rights given by agents/intermediaries in Cochin of foreign buyers; delivery to purchasers by T. Stanes; purchasers obtain export licences using quota rights and export.
Sellers know bids are by agents of foreign buyers for purpose of export; tea cannot be exported otherwise than under licence issued to manufacturer or purchaser of quota.
In petitions, appellants set out manner of sales; in some, no affidavits by State; in others, State contended export by purchasers did not affect character of sales.
No finding by Sales-tax authorities that purchasers were agents of foreign buyers, but case argued on that footing before High Court.
High Court (Vaidialingam J.): sales complete on acceptance of bids, sellers no concern with export by purchasers.
Division Bench: ban under Art. 286(1)(b) requires intimate connection; sale must be integral part, no obligation to export.
Appellants are 18 tea estates growing and manufacturing tea.
Assessees obtained export quotas; sales at Fort Cochin with transfer of export quota rights to purchasers; purchasers (agents of foreign principals) obtained licences and exported.
Assessing authorities accepted appellants' statements as correct, no evidence led.

legal_issues.text: Whether the sale by auction of tea chests with export quota rights at Fort Cochin to agents of foreign buyers is a sale in the course of export out of the territory of India within the meaning of Art. 286(1)(b) of the Constitution, exempt from State sales tax.

petitioner_arguments.text: Sales are in the course of export as they occasion export; integral connection with export; sellers know purpose is export by foreign agents.
Export quota rights transferred with sale; purchasers bound to export as agents fulfilling contractual duty to principals.

respondent_arguments.text: Sales complete on acceptance of bids; sellers have no concern with actual export by purchasers; no obligation to export imposed by contract or statute.
Tea Act enables but does not compel export; purchasers free to divert to local consumption.

court_reasoning.text: To constitute sale in course of export: common intention to export + actual export insufficient; requires series of integrated activities from agreement with foreign buyer to delivery to common carrier; connection so integrated cannot be interrupted without breach.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sale occasions export if bond links contract to exportation inextricably.

court_reasoning.text: Here, knowledge of export intent and sale with quota rights imputes knowledge but no bond; no statutory/contractual obligation to export; sellers lose control post-sale; sales for export, not in course of.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No direct connection making sale and export parts of single transaction.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes prior cases: sales preceding export sale taxable unless property passes in export stream.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Single sale to agent not necessarily in course of export without integral link.

court_reasoning.text: Dissent: Sales to agents of foreign buyers with quota transfer; implicit understanding to export; economic factors compel; integral with export.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Real intention and circumstances create obligation; sales occasion export.

holdings.text: Sale in course of export requires integrated activities with inextricable bond between sale and export; mere knowledge/intent to export and sale with quota rights insufficient without obligation linking them.
Transactions here are sales for export, not in course of export; taxable by State.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Travancore-Cochin v. Bombay Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Sales which occasion export exempt; integrated activities from sale agreement to export.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Travancore-Cochin v. Shanmugha Vilas Cashew Nut Factory
precedents_cited.relevance: 'In the course of' implies connected relation; purchases preparatory to export not exempt.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madras v. Gurviah Naidu & Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Purchases after securing foreign orders not occasion export.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Mysore v. Mysore Shipping & Manufacturing Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Sale to licensed exporter who resells for export not in course of export.

precedents_cited.case_name: East India Tobacco Co. v. State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Only sale under which export made protected; prior purchases not.
Sales where property passes in export stream exempt even if prior sale.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madras v. Madura Tanned Leather Co. (Madras High Court)
precedents_cited.relevance: Sale to agent of foreign buyer may occasion export if privity and integral.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Exempts sales in course of export from State tax; defines via Central Sales Tax Act.

statutes_cited.name: Tea Act, 1953
statutes_cited.relevance: Controls tea export; quotas transferable; enables but does not compel export.

statutes_cited.name: Central Sales Tax Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Deems sale in course of export if occasions export or transfer of title after customs frontier.

statutes_cited.name: Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Act, XI of 1125 M.E.

outcome.summary: By majority (Shah J. for Gajendragadkar C.J., Shah, Sikri JJ.), appeals dismissed holding sales not in course of export; dissenting (Ayyangar J. for Wanchoo, Ayyangar JJ.) would allow. In accordance with majority, appeals dismissed.
outcome.costs: Dismissed with costs. One hearing fee.

key_quotes.text: "A sale in the course of export predicates a connection between the sale and export, the two activities being so integrated that the connection between the two cannot be voluntarily interrupted, without a breach of the contract or the compulsion arising from the nature of the transaction."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines test for 'in the course of export' under Art. 286(1)(b).

key_quotes.text: "The sales were therefore for export, and not in the course of export."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The word 'course' etymologically denotes movement from one point to another, and the expression 'in the course of' not only implies a period of time during which the movement is in progress but postulates also a connected relation."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Shanmugha Vilas, adopted in reasoning.
